docs.lead_paragraph: Lucy Freeman, who died at the end of 2004, thought that there was nothing wrong with being crazy. As a reporter for The New York Times in the 1940's and 50's she worked to remove the stigma of mental illness, even writing a revealing book that chronicled her own psychoanalysis.

headline.main: Exploring Mental Illness and Battling Her Own

docs.abstract: Dr Barron Lerner discusses former Times reporter Lucy Freeman, who died in 2004; describes her work helping to reform public opinion about mental illness, while battling her own personal neurosis through psychoanalysis; Freeman wrote 78 books primarily on emotions and mental health; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Lucy Freeman fought the stigma that plagued her and others suffering from mental illness by chronicling her own psychoanalysis.

docs.lead_paragraph: Are wine drinkers healthier than beer drinkers? If that is the case, it may have less to do with their choice of drink than with what they eat with it.

headline.main: Diet May Drive Data on Beer, Wine and Health

docs.abstract: Danish researcher Dr Morten Gronbaek leads study on overall dietary habits of beer drinkers compared to wine drinkers; research, which is published in BMJ, finds that people purchasing wine generally purchased healthier food along with alcohol than beer drinkers; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: If wine drinkers are healthier than beer drinkers, it may have less to do with their choice of drink than with what they eat with it.

docs.lead_paragraph: Each day, I would dread checking my office mailbox, wondering if another of the overstuffed envelopes with their huge scrawled addresses would turn up. After a few months, my patient had learned that all he needed on the envelope was my last name and our mental health clinic's nine-digit ZIP code. The post office unfailingly delivered his missives. Some days, six or seven letters would arrive at once. Then there would be weeks when I heard nothing at all from him, leaving me to wonder if he was dead or perhaps plotting my death.

headline.main: After Polite Sessions, Letters Filled With Anti-Semitism

docs.abstract: Psychiatrist Ronald Pies describes treating chronic paranoid schizophrenic patient who hounded him with anti-Semitic letters that bordered on threats; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: What do you do when your patient sends you letters full of hate?

docs.lead_paragraph: Children who ice-skate suffer many more head and face injuries than those who roller-skate. Though it may seem natural to assume that the explanation lies with the helmets commonly used by those who are not skating on ice, this does not appear to be the case, researchers reported yesterday. Writing in The British Journal of Sports Medicine, they said the key to reducing head injuries might instead be in the wrists.

headline.main: For Ice Skaters, a Higher Chance of Head Injury

docs.abstract: Christy Knox and Dawn Comstock of Columbus Children's Research Institute, Ohio, lead study on head injuries sustained from ice skating falls; research, which is published in British Journal of Sports Medicine, suggests that more head injuries occur because skaters are unable to stop falling with their wrists and hands; researchers are working on development of special wrist guards that would not slip on ice; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Children who ice-skate suffer many more head and face injuries than those who roller-skate.

docs.lead_paragraph: Carbon monoxide poisoning is the most common kind of accidental poisoning in the United States, playing a role in 40,000 emergency rooms visits a year. But while it is increasingly unusual for victims to die at the hospital, a new study suggests that when many are sent home, their problems are far from over.

headline.main: After Crisis, Carbon Monoxide Still Takes a Toll

docs.abstract: Christopher R Henry of Minneapolis Heart Institute Foundation leads study on risk of heart damage from carbon monoxide poisoning; research, which is published in Journal of the American Medical Assn, suggests that doctors closely monitor any patients exposed to carbon monoxide for heart muscle damage; finds that they are at considerably higher risk of heart attack than those not exposed to carbon monoxide (S)
docs.snippet: When many victims of carbon monoxide poisoning are sent home from the hospital, their problems are far from over.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN MEDICAL ASSN

docs.lead_paragraph: Married women under extreme stress who reach out and hold their husbands' hands feel immediate relief, neuroscientists have found in what they say is the first study of how human touch affects the neural response to threatening situations. The soothing effect of the touch could be seen in scans of areas deep in the brain that are involved in registering emotional and physical alarm.

headline.main: Holding Loved One's Hand Can Calm Jittery Neurons

docs.abstract: Dr James A Coan of University of Virginia leads study on effects of married partner's touch on relieving stress; research, which is published in journal Psychological Science, finds that women who are told to anticipate mild electric shock are soothed by touch of their partner; highest levels of relief were achieved by couples measured to have deepest levels of intimacy (M)
docs.snippet: A new study is the first to examine how human touch affects the neural response to threatening situations.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite the wealth of information about the risks and benefits of hormone therapy, women face difficult choices when contemplating treatment. There is no one-size-fits-all answer, doctors say. Ultimately, each woman must make her own risk-benefit assessment, taking into account the severity of menopausal symptoms, general health and the potential long-term risks of treatment.

headline.main: Basing Choice on Risk vs. Benefit

docs.abstract: Despite concerns over health risks of hormone replacement therapy, women that experience significant negative symptoms of menopause can choose from variety of treatments for relief; research shows that almost all hormone treatments come with some risk, but potential benefits should be weighed against risks (M)
docs.snippet: Despite the wealth of information about the risks and benefits of hormone therapy, women face difficult choices when contemplating treatment.      There is no one-size-fits-all answer, doctors say. Ultimately, each woman must make her own...

docs.lead_paragraph: People who fare poorly on tests intended to assess mental skills are at greater risk of early death, a new study reports. Writing in Psychosomatic Medicine, researchers say they found a strong link between slower reaction times and a higher mortality rate in a given period. People who did poorly on memory tests also had a somewhat higher mortality rate.

headline.main: Do Slower Reactions Mean an Earlier Death?

docs.abstract: Beverly A Shipley of University of Edinburgh leads study on longevity that suggests people who do not score well on tests of mental acuity are at greater risk of early death; research is published in journal Psychosomatic Medicine; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: People who fare poorly on tests intended to assess mental skills are at greater risk of early death, a new study reports.

docs.lead_paragraph: For many years, transplant surgeons around the world rejected use of organs from cadaver donors age 60 or older because they tended not to last as long as organs taken from younger people. But about 20 years ago, a few transplant surgeons began giving kidneys from older donors to a small number of recipients 50 and older.

headline.main: Test Expands Donor Pool For Kidneys

docs.abstract: Dr Giuseppe Remuzzi of Mario Negri Institute of Pharmacological Research, Italy, heads research on kidney transplants that leads to development of rating system for kidney health that can be used prior to transplant; system, which involves biopsy, is currently used to evaluate potential kidney donations from older individuals; research is described in New England Journal of Medicine (M)
docs.snippet: A standard test performed on older kidneys can gauge which kidneys will be as effective in transplants as younger ones.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: NEGRI, MARIO, INSTITUTE OF PHARMACOLOGICAL RESEARCH

docs.lead_paragraph: In last summer's prize-winning R-rated film ''Me and You and Everyone We Know,'' a barely pubescent boy is seduced into oral sex by two girls perhaps a year older, and his 6-year-old brother logs on to a pornographic chat room and solicits a grown woman with instant messages about ''poop.'' Is this what your teenage children are watching? If so, what message are they getting about sexual mores, and what effect will it have on their behavior?

headline.main: Children, Media and Sex: A Big Book of Blank Pages

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses how media-rich environment shapes children's views about sex; research suggests that children who view more television with sexual content behave as though they are 9 to 17 months older than they actually are; photo; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: What message are children getting about sexual mores, and what effect will it have on their behavior?
